intro: Cascarilla officinalis, commonly known as the Mexican quinine tree, is a small to medium-sized evergreen tree native to Central America and parts of South America. It belongs to the Rubiaceae family, which includes other economically important plants like coffee and gardenia. The plant is characterized by its simple, opposite leaves and small, fragrant white flowers that bloom in clusters. Its bark and roots contain compounds used in traditional medicine, particularly for their antipyretic and analgesic properties. The tree thrives in tropical and subtropical climates, often found in moist, well-drained soils.
